Description: Upper part of terracotta figure of Harpocrates, the infant Horus. Hollow and mould made. Traces of white coating. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with common quartz, mica and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Made in Naukratis, with identical piece found on site in the 1899 season (Gutch in Hogarth 1898-9, 92 n.5, pl.13, no.191) dated Ptolemaic or Roman period. A number of Harpocrates from the same mould were found at Naukratis (British Museum Bailey 2008, no.3060 GR1886,0401.1442, Bristol H2814 and probably Cambridge NA629). Variants of this macrophallic reclining Harpocrates with side knot type has been found in Saqqara. The Naukratis terracotta workshop area was dated to the 3rd and 2nd century BC (Bailey 2008, nos. 3058-60), though Late Hellenistic (Török 1995, no.72) and 1st-2nd century AD dates for similar pieces has been suggested (Fischer 1994, no.575). Variants have been found at Theadelphia (Weber 1914, no.60) or unprovenanced (Sotheby’s Sale Catalogue, 18 May 1987, lot 113) and they were making similar examples in a terracotta shop at Memphis (Engelbach et al. 1915, pl. 61: 45(1)).
